awd_titl_txt: Expanding access to webcam-based online data collection for developmental research
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will expand, Lookit, an online platform designed to conduct and promote developmental research. The platform will enable families to  participate in research studies while in their own homes, using their own computers.  The researchers will recruit study participants and make it possible for other researchers to post studies on the Lookit system; thereby, creating a tool for researchers, teachers, and doctors to learn  how children think and grow. The project will expand knowledge about child development by making it more practical for researchers to measure small effects, include appropriate controls, work with special populations, and/or observe individual differences across repeated sessions. It will also provide a way to conduct more reproducible work, so that studies from different laboratories can more reliably build on each other. Lookit will broaden family participation in developmental studies, so that research better represents the variety of family structures, educational backgrounds, and communities of American families. In addition, Lookit will reduce barriers faced by researchers who study children but do not have access to laboratories.

In-person developmental research is subject to practical constraints that limit which questions can be addressed. In particular, it is often impractical to work with large numbers of children in order to measure small or graded effects, recruit special populations, conduct longitudinal studies, or observe behaviors in homes. The proposed project aims to reduce these barriers by developing a common resource for online testing, allowing researchers to post their studies on the Lookit platform so families can participate at home. The site will be centrally hosted, with a shared participant userbase, but researchers will control access to their own data. The researchers will develop the functionality needed to bring the current system to scale; recruit a large, diverse participant userbase to enable rapid collection of large datasets online; and refine the researcher interface and produce training materials for researchers using the platform.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This award resulted in the public launch of Lookit (http://lookit.mit.edu), an online platform that allows families to participate from home in research about how babies and children learn. The platform is now available as a resource for the research community, enabling any researcher to post a study and collect data online. In particular, outcomes of the award include web development to bring the initial single-lab tool to scale (Specific Aim 1), recruitment of a large, diverse user base of families who participate in studies to allow collection of large datasets online (Specific Aim 2), and improvements to the researcher interface and development of training materials and resources for the scientists who use the platform (Specific Aim 3.)


Lookit was publicly launched in June 2020, and as of November 2022, there are now over 140 principal investigators across 7 countries with access agreements to use Lookit, and we are actively running over 75 concurrent studies (over 200 studies have been active in the last year). There are over 900 researchers in Lookit’s Slack workspace, our primary venue for providing technical support as well as for researchers to discuss experimental design issues, at the time of writing. Launching allowed us to immediately leverage individual labs’ recruitment efforts; in the past year there have been over 11,000 study sessions run on Lookit from over 2900 unique children.


In-person developmental research is subject to practical constraints that limit the questions that can reasonably be addressed. Lookit aims to reduce these barriers and expanding the scope of methodology available to researchers, implementing a valuable community resource. Lookit makes it easier for researchers to work that requires any of the following: large sample sizes in order to measure small or graded effects, run appropriate controls, and ensure adequate power; recruitment of special populations; observation of natural in-home behavior; representative sampling across socioeconomic groups; and repeated sessions with the same children. Lookit also stands to advance scientific knowledge by making developmental research more reproducible, allowing for more cumulative progress.


By expanding access to Lookit among researchers, the present award has lowered the barriers to investigators who are not affiliated with an established child lab - including many young investigators as well as educators, clinicians, and others whose work directly addresses families quality of life. Similarly, it has enabled undergraduates to conduct research more readily as part of their education. Finally, Lookit broadens participation by families in developmental studies to reach a more typical population in terms of parental income and education level, as well as a geographically dispersed population. In addition to reducing the sampling bias typical of in-lab studies, this allows opportunities for increasing scientific literacy as parents help to investigate how their children think and learn.


Last Modified: 12/08/2022
Modified by: Laura E Schulz
